metadata.h1: Building my 2020 reading list with a simple Python script

all_paragraphs: I concede that I didn’t read too many books in the past a few years. With MOOC (Massive Open Online Courses) evolution started in 2012, I spent most of my spare time across Coursera, edX, and LinkedIn Learning. Many contents on MOOC illustrate knowledge (e.g. programming techniques, statistics concepts, etc) very well, these greatly help with my early career growth; however, I always feel something is missing with using only MOOC, but I could not tell what it is.

Today, at the end of 2019, after finish reading “Drive: The Surprising Truth About What Motivates Us” and started enjoying “The Hard Thing About Hard Things: Building a Business When There Are No Easy Answers”, it is quite amazing (for me) that reading books, physical holding them on hand, can trigger lots of reflection and also help connect many random thoughts. These mental activities enforce the understanding and lead one’s thoughts to go much deeper beyond the text itself. This is such a unique experience that I did not understand in the past with any MOOC platform! So I made up my mind to set one new year resolution: read 12 books in 2020.

Which books should I prioritize then? Given my specific field and career direction, I like to focus more on the business and leadership side in my first “reading year”. Besides a few great recommendations (e.g. “The Hard Thing About Hard Things”, “Trillion Dollar Coach”) from knowledgable friends, I am still short of great business & leadership related books. So I turned to the famous “New York Times Best Seller” for help: if a book sells so well to be qualified for the list, it must have some insights worth reading.

After I opened the most recent business list in the New York Times (link), it shows 10 book titles, and every month the list could change! This is great if I already read most of them and just take the list for an incremental selection, but clearly that’s not my case, so how to prioritize a few out of all historic “Best Sellers”? I tried to search in Google for something like “all-time NY Times Best Sellers”, but it returns no meaningful results: maybe no one has a special need as mine. I am trying to use historic data to support curating my first-year reading list, while others may read most of them already :(

Still, I don’t want to give up, and just randomly pick a few out of the most recent list is definitely not my style: I want to use hard-core data to support my choice, I want to know the most popular books in NY Times Best Seller List history; however, the data is scattered across multiple web pages and not handy to read. Facing such a challenge, what a Data Scientist would do? Well, he/she is going to write some code. My goal is clear, get all historic NY Times Best Seller lists (Business topic), and then assess the books to build my 2020 reading list.
My workflow is very straightforward and simple; it has three steps.
For the New York Times website, all the URL has the structure like https://www.nytimes.com/books/best-sellers/2019/08/01/business-books/, with the year and month being the only variable. Checked!

For the web element, the top 10 list for each month is organized inside an ordered list (“ol”) with class name “css-12yzwg4”. The contents are saved inside the division (“div”) with class name “css-xe4cfy”, and each book is one item of the contents. The book title has “h3” tag with class name “css-5pe77f”, and book author has “p” tag with class name “css-hjukut”. Checked!
Now we get all the key elements layout and they are all consistent across the URLs, this is good news for continuing to the next step.

I have not been using Requests/BeautifulSoup for a while, so it is nice to take a reference from other’s work. With a search on “python requests beautifulsoup”, I found one nice article to reference: https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-work-with-web-data-using-requests-and-beautiful-soup-with-python-3.
